awd_abstract_narration:
This project investigates topics at the confluence of geometric analysis, topology, and mathematical physics. The overarching goal is to develop and relate the analysis and topology of singular geometric objects. Many questions in geometry and related areas of physics, such as general relativity and holography, involve singular spaces and can be profitably understood by introducing smooth manifolds with corners, which capture the nature of singularities. Often one can recast the questions in a manner adapted to the manifold with corners and subsequently apply a toolbox of strong techniques known as "geometric microlocal analysis." One aspect of this project is to contribute to the development and application of these techniques to a large class of singular spaces (stratified spaces), allowing analytic tools to be brought to bear on algebraic and topological questions. Another aspect of the project is to promote the entry of new investigators into this active area of research. The investigator will further develop a research monograph on the subject and organize courses and conferences to disseminate these techniques and results.
 
An important example of a question at the confluence of geometric analysis, topology, and mathematical physics is to understand the signature of stratified spaces, such as those arising as the zeros of polynomials in several variables. The investigator and collaborators have extended the class of spaces on which the signature can be understood analytically and have shown that it satisfies some of the main properties of the signatures of smooth spaces. In this project explicit formulae will be established for the signature and its twisted analogues. The project also aims to develop a topological surgery theory for singular spaces and show that the signature operator naturally defines maps from this sequence. Other projects involve understanding an invariant of representations of the fundamental group of a locally symmetric space by changing the usual algebraic perspective to a geometric one.

por.por_cntn:
Many problems in geometry and related areas of physics such as general relativity and holography take place on non-compact or singular spaces and can be profitably understood by introducing smooth manifolds with corners. Often one can recast the problem in a manner adapted to the manifold with corners and the apply a toolbox of strong techniques known as `geometric microlocal analysis' to solve the original problem. Using these techniques this project sought to develop and relate the analysis, geometry, and topology of singular geometric objects.
Here geometry refers to properties like the presence and shape of the singularities and the way the space degenerates around the singularity, analysis refers to the behavior of functions and their derivatives on the space, particularly to their behavior at the singularities, and topology refers roughly to properties of a space that do not change when the space is deformed continuously, such as whether or not the space is connected. 
One beautiful circle of ideas that combines all of these aspects together is known as `index theory' as it centers on the Atiyah-Singer index theorem. One thing we learn from this theorem is how the number of solutions to a differential equation depends on the topology of the space on which those solutions live. The theory then goes on to allow topological relations between spaces to be encoded in spaces of solutions to differential equations. One of the successes of the projects funded by this grant was to extend this circle of ideas to a class of singular spaces known as `stratified spaces'. Often a singular space will show up in studies that center on smooth spaces and when this happens it usually retains some of the structure of the smooth space, in that case we end up with a stratified space.One project successfully extended the Atiyah-Singer index theorem itself on stratified spaces. Another project extended some of the deeper implications of index theory,those encoding topological relations known as `surgeries', to stratified spaces.Another pair of projects worked out the extension of a subtle related invariant, known as `analytic torsion', to some classes of stratified spaces and other singular geometriesknown as `sub-Riemannian'.
General relativity and holography were involved in another project funded by this grant. Holography is a contemporary approach to physical theories that posits a duality between a physical theory taking place in the bulk of a system and a physical system taking place on the boundary `at infinity'. One well studied instance of his is known as the Anti-de-Sitter/Conformal Field Theory (or AdS/CFT) correspondence which relates gravity in the bulk with a `conformal field theory' on the boundary. Mathematically the geometry of the bulk is governed by the Einstein equation. One project funded by this grant studied what happens if the bulk geometry is allowed to satisfy a more general gravitational theory specified by a `Lovelock equation'. The PI showed that many of the fundamental resultsfor the Einstein theory continue to hold for the more general Lovelock theory.

An important part of this project was to provide research experience to PhD students, as well as to communicate the results in a manner that is accessible to a broader mathematical audience including by various minicourses and expository notes.
